questions.text: A 78-year-old female presented with edema of the left upper limb due to poor venous return. Examination revealed an aneurysm of the ascending aorta that was impinging on a large vein lying immediately anterosuperior to it, most likely the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The left brachiocephalic vein crosses obliquely in front of the arch of the aorta from left to right to join the right brachiocephalic vein and form the superior vena cava
  • An aneurysm of the ascending aorta can impinge upon this vein due to its anterosuperior location.
  • The azygos vein arches over the right lung root and is posterior, not lying anterosuperior to the ascending aorta (Option A ruled out)
  • The internal thoracic vein runs along the posterior surface of the anterior chest wall, not adjacent to the ascending aorta (Option B ruled out)
  • The left superior intercostal vein drains the upper left intercostal spaces and arches over the aortic arch, but it is smaller and not directly responsible for major upper limb drainage (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • The left brachiocephalic vein lies anterosuperior to the aortic arch and can be compressed by an aortic aneurysm
  • Compression may lead to edema of the left upper limb and face.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is found to have a mid-line tumor of the thymus gland that is impinging posteriorly on a blood vessel. The affected vessel is most likely the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A midline tumor of the thymus typically lies in the anterior superior mediastinum and may impinge posteriorly on the left brachiocephalic vein, which crosses horizontally from left to right just behind the thymus (Label B is correct)
  • Label A is the right brachiocephalic vein, which is more vertical and less likely to be directly posterior to a midline thymic mass (Option B ruled out)
  • Label C is the right subclavian vein, which lies more laterally and not directly posterior to the thymus (Option D ruled out)
  • Label D is the arch of the aorta, which is inferior and less immediately posterior to the thymic body compared to the left brachiocephalic vein (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • The left brachiocephalic vein lies directly posterior to the thymus
  • Thymic masses in children can lead to venous compression syndromes.

choices.text: The lower lobe from the lingula
The upper lobe from the lingula
The lower lobe from both the middle and upper lobes
The middle lobe from the upper lobe

questions.text: The minor (horizontal) fissure separates:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The minor (horizontal) fissure is present only in the right lung and separates the middle lobe from the upper lobe (Option D is correct)
  • The lingula is a feature of the left lung, not the right, and is separated from the lower lobe by the oblique fissure, not the horizontal fissure (Options A and B ruled out)
  • The oblique fissure separates the lower lobe from both the middle and upper lobes, not the horizontal fissure (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Horizontal fissure exists only in the right lung
  • It separates middle and upper lobes
  • Lingula is a left lung structure; not involved with the horizontal fissure.

questions.text: Your patient, an 86-year-old female who has been bed-ridden and lying supine for many weeks, has developed a right lung abscess that is draining by gravity into one particular region of the lung. Where is the most likely site of fluid accumulation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the supine position, gravity causes aspirated material or draining fluid (like from a lung abscess) to collect in the posteriorly located segments
  • The superior segment of the lower lobe is the most dependent region of the lung in a supine patient, making it the commonest site of fluid accumulation (Option D is correct)
  • The apical segment of the upper lobe is higher and non-dependent (Option A ruled out)
  • The lingula is part of the left lung, not the right, and is not gravity-dependent in this position (Option B ruled out)
  • The lower lobe in general includes multiple segments; without specificity, it’s less accurate than identifying the superior segment (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • In supine patients, fluid/aspirates most commonly collect in the superior segment of the lower lobe
  • Patient positioning critically influences lung segment involvement in aspiration or abscess drainage.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought in with coughing, and you are told by her mother that she had been playing with some beads and had apparently aspirated one (gotten it into her airway). Where would you expect it to most likely be?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In children and adults, aspirated foreign bodies most commonly lodge in the right main bronchus, which is wider, shorter, and more vertical than the left
  • Label 4 in the image corresponds to the right lower lobe bronchus, the most gravity-dependent part of the respiratory tract in both upright and supine positions (Option A is correct)
  • Label 2 is the left lower lobe, less commonly involved in aspiration (Option B ruled out)
  • Label 3 is the right upper lobe bronchus, not a common site unless patient is supine and aspiration is minor (Option C ruled out)
  • Label 1 is the trachea, which is typically bypassed by small aspirated objects en route to a bronchus (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Right main bronchus is the most common site for aspirated objects
  • Right lower lobe bronchus is most commonly involved due to anatomy and gravity.

questions.text: In a post-soccer match brawl, a 35-year-old man was stabbed in the back with a knife that just nicked his left lung halfway between its apex and diaphragmatic surface. Which part of the lung was most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The inferior lobe of the left lung extends posteriorly and occupies a large portion of the back, especially the area between the apex and diaphragm, making it the most likely site of injury (Option B is correct)
  • The hilum is located medially, near the root of the lung-not posterior-so unlikely to be injured from a back stab (Option A ruled out)
  • The lingula is on the anterior aspect of the upper lobe of the left lung, not posterior (Option C ruled out)
  • The middle lobe exists only on the right lung, not the left (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • The inferior lobe lies posteriorly, especially vulnerable in posterior thoracic injuries
  • The lingula is an anterior left-sided structure
  • The middle lobe is present only on the right lung.

choices.text: It is slightly smaller than the left lung
It has a lingular segmental bronchus
It occupies the rightmost portion of the mediastinum
Its upper lobar bronchus lies behind and above the right pulmonary artery

questions.text: Which statement is true about the right lung?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The right superior (upper) lobar bronchus, also known as the eparterial bronchus, is unique in that it arises above and behind the right pulmonary artery (Option D is correct)
  • The right lung is larger, not smaller, because the left lung is reduced in size by the presence of the heart and cardiac notch (Option A ruled out)
  • The lingula is a feature of the left lung, not the right, and has no corresponding segmental bronchus in the right lung (Option B ruled out)
  • The mediastinum is a central thoracic structure, and no lung "occupies" it; the lungs flank it-so the right lung doesn't occupy its rightmost part (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • The right upper lobar bronchus (eparterial) is located above the pulmonary artery
  • The left lung contains the lingula and is smaller
  • The right lung has three lobes, no lingula.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is related to the area marked in the diagram below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The area marked corresponds to the arch of the azygos vein, which curves over the right main bronchus to drain into the superior vena cava (Option A is correct)
  • The superior vena cava lies vertically along the right heart border, but lower than the marked region (Option B ruled out)
  • The inferior vena cava lies in the lower right thorax and does not reach the upper mediastinum (Option C ruled out)
  • The brachiocephalic trunk lies anterior to the trachea, not in the posterior paratracheal region shown here (Option D ruled out)
  • Azygos fissure and azygos lobe may also be seen as a normal anatomical variant in this region:
    • The azygos lobe is not a true lobe but a portion of the right upper lobe displaced by an aberrant course of the azygos vein
    • The azygos fissure appears as a fine curvilinear shadow with the azygos vein as a central dot, created by invagination of pleura
    • Important to differentiate from pathological findings on chest X-ray

Key Takeaways:

  • The azygos vein forms the arch over the right lung root and is visible on X-ray
  • Azygos lobe is a normal variant, not a pathological structure
  • Recognizing the azygos fissure prevents misdiagnosis on imaging

questions.text: Which is the most superior structure at the hilum of the left lung?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • At the hilum of the left lung, the pulmonary artery lies superior to other structures, making it the most superiorly placed (Option D is correct)
  • The left bronchus lies posteroinferior to the pulmonary artery (Option C ruled out)
  • The pulmonary veins are located anteroinferiorly, below the bronchus and artery (Option A ruled out)
  • The bronchial artery, though small and located near the bronchus, does not occupy the most superior position(Option B ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Left lung hilum arrangement: Pulmonary artery (superior), bronchus (posterior), pulmonary veins (inferior)
  • Mnemonic: "RALS" – Right lung: Artery Anterior, Left lung: Artery Superior.

questions.text: What is the inferior most structure of the right hilum?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the right lung hilum, the inferior pulmonary vein lies in the lowest (inferior-most) position and is responsible for draining oxygenated blood back to the left atrium (Option B is correct)
  • The pulmonary artery lies superiorly and anteriorly in the right hilum (Option C ruled out)
  • The bronchus lies posteriorly, above the inferior pulmonary vein (Option D ruled out)
  • The right atrium is part of the heart, not a structure of the lung hilum (Option A ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Inferior pulmonary vein is the lowest structure in the hilum of both lungs
  • Right hilum arrangement (top to bottom): Eparterial bronchus, pulmonary artery, hyparterial bronchus, pulmonary veins.

questions.text: How many bronchopulmonary segments are there in the right and left lungs, respectively?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Each lung is divided into bronchopulmonary segments, which are functionally and anatomically discrete units, each supplied by a segmental (tertiary) bronchus
  • Right lung consistently has 10 segments (Option A correct)
  • Left lung is classically said to have 10 segments, although in some individuals, two segments may fuse (especially in the upper lobe), making it appear as 8 or 9 — but anatomically, 10 segments are still recognized (Option A correct)
  • Options suggesting 11 segments are anatomically incorrect (Options C and D ruled out)
  • The configuration of 9, 10 implies asymmetry not typically taught in standard anatomical classification (Option B ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Both right and left lungs have 10 bronchopulmonary segments
  • Segments are independent units, allowing segmental resection in surgery.

questions.text: Bronchopulmonary segments are aerated by which of the following bronchi?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Each bronchopulmonary segment is supplied by a tertiary (segmental) bronchus, which defines the segment and is its primary air supply.
  • Secondary (lobar) bronchi supply lung lobes, not individual segments (Option D ruled out)
  • Terminal bronchioles are distal airways within a segment but do not define or directly aerate the entire segment (Option B ruled out)
  • Respiratory bronchioles are even further downstream and contribute to gas exchange, not segmental ventilation (Option A ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Tertiary (segmental) bronchi define and aerate bronchopulmonary segments
  • Knowing the segmental supply is key in segmentectomy and lobectomy.

questions.text: A patients Bronchogram showed the presence of a tumor, causing partial occlusion of the eparterial bronchus. Which of the following bronchopulmonary segments are likely to receive decreased airflow?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The eparterial bronchus is a branch of the right main bronchus that lies above the pulmonary artery and supplies the apical, anterior, and posterior segments of the right upper lobe.
  • The lateral and medial segments belong to the middle lobe, supplied by the hyparterial bronchus (Option A ruled out)
  • The basal segments (including medial and lateral basal) are part of the lower lobe, also supplied by hyparterial bronchi (Option B ruled out)
  • The medial segment in Option D is from the middle lobe, not the upper lobe, and not supplied by the eparterial bronchus (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Eparterial bronchus supplies: apical, anterior, posterior segments of right upper lobe
  • All other segments in the right lung are supplied by hyparterial bronchi
  • Important for segmental bronchial mapping in bronchoscopy and surgery

questions.text: Up to which level does the bronchial artery supplies blood to the lungs?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The bronchial arteries provide nutritional (systemic) blood supply to the lung tissue
  • Their supply reaches up to the respiratory bronchioles, where anastomoses with the pulmonary circulationbegin.
  • Tertiary bronchioles is a non-standard term; likely refers to segmental bronchi, which are supplied but not the limit of distribution (Option A ruled out)
  • Alveolar ducts are supplied by pulmonary capillaries, not bronchial arteries (Option C ruled out)
  • Terminal bronchioles are proximal to respiratory bronchioles and still within the supply territory, but not the most distal point of supply (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Bronchial arteries supply lung tissue up to respiratory bronchioles
  • Gas exchange regions (alveoli, alveolar ducts) are supplied by pulmonary arteries
  • Important in distinguishing dual blood supply of the lungs.

choices.text: It is drained by independent intrasegmental branch of pulmonary vein
It is the largest subdivision of a lobe
It is named according to the segmental bronchus supplying it

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the bronchopulmonary segment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bronchopulmonary segments are drained by intersegmental (not intrasegmental) branches of the pulmonary veins, which run in the connective tissue septa between segments (Option A is false and thus correct)
  • It is indeed the largest functional and anatomical subdivision of a lobe (Option B is correct)
  • Each segment is named based on the segmental (tertiary) bronchus supplying it (Option C is correct)
  • Because each segment has its own bronchus and arterial supply, it is surgically resectable without affecting other segments (Option D is correct)

Key Takeaways:

  • Pulmonary veins are intersegmental, not intrasegmental
  • Bronchopulmonary segments are independent surgical units
  • Named after the segmental bronchus

choices.text: They lie between external intercostal and internal intercostal muscle
Derivatives from T7 to T11 supply the abdominal wall
Derivatives from T4 and T5 are typical in type
It is located below the intercostal artery

questions.text: The given image shows the posterior thoracic wall. Which of the following statements is false about the structure marked A within the intercostal space?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The structure marked A is the intercostal nerve, part of the neurovascular bundle found in the costal groove of a rib
  • The correct vertical arrangement of the intercostal neurovascular bundle (from superior to inferior) is: Vein - Artery - Nerve (VAN)
    Hence, the nerve lies below the artery, not the other way around - making Option D false.
  • Intercostal nerves do lie between the internal and innermost intercostal muscles (Option A is true)
  • Intercostal nerves T7 to T11 are also called thoracoabdominal nerves and supply the abdominal wall (Option B is true)
  • T4 and T5 intercostal nerves are typical in their distribution and anatomy (Option C is true)

Key Takeaways:

  • Order of structures in intercostal space: Vein, Artery, Nerve (VAN)
  • Intercostal nerve lies below the artery, not above it
  • T7–T11 intercostals continue into the abdominal wall.

choices.text: Arise from dorsal rami of C2, C3, and C4
Descends in the left pleural space
Supplies the parietal peritoneum on the diaphragm
Passes through the vena caval opening in the diaphragm

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the left phrenic nerve?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The left phrenic nerve, like the right, supplies motor innervation to the diaphragm and sensory innervation to the central diaphragmatic pleura, mediastinal pleura, and diaphragmatic peritoneum (Option C is correct)
  • It arises from the ventral rami of C3, C4, and C5, not the dorsal rami, and not C2 (Option A ruled out)
  • The phrenic nerve descends within the fibrous pericardium, not the pleural space (Option B ruled out)
  • It passes through the diaphragm independently, not via the vena caval opening, which transmits the IVC and right phrenic nerve only (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Phrenic nerve arises from C3-C5 (ventral rami)
  • Left phrenic nerve supplies diaphragmatic peritoneum
  • Only the right phrenic nerve passes through the vena caval opening

questions.text: A patient with pericarditis is complaining of pain in the left shoulder and neck. Through which of the following nerves is this sensation carried?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pericardial pain, especially from pericarditis, is referred to the shoulder and neck due to irritation of the central diaphragmatic pleura and fibrous pericardium
  • These areas are innervated by the phrenic nerve (C3-C5), which also innervates the skin over the shoulder via C4 dermatomes (Option C is correct)
  • The deep and superficial cardiac plexuses carry autonomic fibers to the heart but are not involved in transmitting somatic referred pain (Options A and B ruled out)
  • The subcostal nerve is the ventral ramus of T12, which innervates abdominal wall structures-not involved in pericardial or shoulder sensation (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Phrenic nerve carries somatic afferents from the pericardium and refers pain to shoulder and neck (C3-C5 dermatomes)
  • Cardiac plexuses carry autonomic fibers, not somatic pain
  • Referred pain patterns are key in localizing visceral pathology.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with chest pain, dyspnea, and weight loss. Chest X-ray showed an elevated right dome of the diaphragm. CT revealed a tumor invading the right lung surface anterior to the hilum. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved by the tumor?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The phrenic nerve descends anterior to the root of the lung, closely related to the mediastinal pleura and fibrous pericardium
  • A tumor invading the anterior surface of the right lung near the hilum can damage the right phrenic nerve, leading to paralysis of the right hemidiaphragm, seen as elevation on chest X-ray.
  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the right subclavian artery (right) or aortic arch (left) and is not adjacent to the lung hilum (Option A ruled out)
  • Intercostal nerves run along the inferior margins of ribs, not near the lung hilum (Option B ruled out)
  • The vagus nerve passes posterior to the root of the lung, so it is not in the path of an anteriorly placed tumor (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Phrenic nerve injury = elevated diaphragm on X-ray
  • The phrenic nerve lies anterior to the lung root, vulnerable to anterior mediastinal or hilar tumors
  • Essential for diaphragmatic movement and respiratory function.

questions.text: A patient presented with paradoxical respiration. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Paradoxical respiration (diaphragm moves upward during inspiration instead of downward) indicates diaphragmatic paralysis, typically due to phrenic nerve damage
  • In the image, label B corresponds to the phrenic nerve, which descends anterior to the anterior scalene muscle, lateral to the great vessels (Option C is correct)
  • Label A is likely a branch of the vagus nerve, not involved in direct diaphragmatic control (Option D ruled out)
  • Label C is located centrally, near the trachea, possibly the recurrent laryngeal nerve, which controls vocal cords but not respiration (Option A ruled out)
  • Label D is more lateral and inferior, not following the known course of the phrenic nerve (Option B ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Phrenic nerve injury causes diaphragmatic paralysis → paradoxical respiration
  • Phrenic nerve runs anterior to scalene muscle, enters thorax anterior to lung root
  • Essential in diaphragmatic motor control (C3–C5).

choices.text: It runs anterior to scalenus anterior
It lies posterior to brachial plexus
It lies posterior to subclavian artery
It runs behind the left hilum

questions.text: A patient is suspected with phrenic nerve palsy. On asking the patient to inspire, you observe the following in the diaphragm during fluoroscopy. Which of the following statements is correct about the course of the nerve involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The phrenic nerve runs anterior to the scalenus anterior muscle, deep to the prevertebral fascia, and enters the thorax by passing posterior to the subclavian vein and anterior to the subclavian artery (Option A is correct)
  • It lies anterior to the brachial plexus, not posterior (Option B ruled out)
  • It lies anterior to the subclavian artery, not posterior (Option C ruled out)
  • It passes anterior to the lung hilum, both on the left and right sides (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Phrenic nerve = anterior to scalenus anterior, anterior to hilum, anterior to subclavian artery
  • Injury to the phrenic nerve causes diaphragmatic paralysis, seen as paradoxical movement on fluoroscopy.

questions.text: A cancerous growth from the body of the 9th thoracic vertebra exerts pressure anterolaterally. Which structure lies in direct contact with this growth?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The greater thoracic splanchnic nerve arises from the thoracic sympathetic chain (T5-T9) and courses anterolaterally over the vertebral bodies to enter the abdomen through the diaphragm, making it the structure in direct contact with the anterolateral surface of the T9 vertebral body (Option D is correct)
  • The right sympathetic trunk lies more posterior-lateral to the vertebral body and is not directly in contact with the anterior surface (Option C ruled out)
  • The right vagus nerve descends posterior to the root of the lung, but is more anterior and medial to the vertebral bodies in the thorax (Option A ruled out)
  • The right phrenic nerve is located anterior to the lung root, far from the vertebral body (Option B ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Greater thoracic splanchnic nerve (T5-T9) runs anterolaterally over thoracic vertebral bodies
  • Directly vulnerable to vertebral body pathologies
  • Important for autonomic innervation to abdominal viscera.

questions.text: While viewing an exploratory surgery on a patient injured in an automobile accident, you see the surgeon elevate the esophagus off the vertebral bodies and look in the area between the azygos vein and descending aorta. What structure was she most likely looking for?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The thoracic duct ascends in the posterior mediastinum, lying between the azygos vein (right) and the descending thoracic aorta (left), posterior to the esophagus - this is the precise area the surgeon would inspect during such a procedure (Option D is correct)
  • The greater thoracic splanchnic nerve lies anterolateral to the vertebral bodies, not directly between the aorta and azygos vein (Option A ruled out)
  • The left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the arch of aorta, far superior and anterior to the thoracic duct's location (Option B ruled out)
  • The right pulmonary artery lies anterior to the esophagus and within the pericardium, not in the posterior mediastinum (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Thoracic duct lies posterior to esophagus, between azygos vein and descending aorta
  • Most important lymphatic channel of the body
  • Vulnerable in posterior mediastinal surgeries.

questions.text: A frail, elderly man, suspected of having widespread cancer of the lungs and bronchi, is brought in for bronchoscopic examination. The instrument is inserted into the airway, where it accidentally punctures the thin, brittle posterior wall of the diseased right main bronchus. A sudden gush of blood immediately indicates that the instrument has also torn the wall of the blood vessel immediately behind the right main bronchus, i.e., the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The azygos vein arches over and behind the right main bronchus before draining into the superior vena cava, placing it in direct posterior relation to the right bronchus (Option A is correct)
  • The left brachiocephalic artery is located on the left side of the mediastinum, and has no anatomical relation to the right main bronchus (Option B ruled out)
  • The pericardiacophrenic artery runs with the phrenic nerve, along the pericardium, far anterior to the bronchi (Option C ruled out)
  • The right pulmonary vein lies inferior and anterior to the right main bronchus, not posterior (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Azygos vein lies posterior to the right main bronchus
  • Vulnerable during bronchoscopic procedures, especially in posterior wall perforations
  • Critical to recognize mediastinal vascular relationships.
